subject: Re: [junit] junit on large scale
msgSnippet: ... Tests are not overhead; they are the safety net that /enables/ you to make changes confidently. They /save/ you time & effort. Without tests, how do you
messageBody:
Kevin O'Sullivan wrote:

> Hi - I'm attempting to introduce junit testing techniques into where I work.
> So far I've used it on a small scale, writing junit tests for enhancement
> changes to existing code.
> We have some large projects, along the lines of web booking engines for
> travel agents, that already exist. One of the concerns that I (and
> developers) have is that we will end up with thousands of test cases, many
> of which will involve using substantial amounts of MockObjects to set up
> test cases and that all this will become too much of an overhead to manage &
> maintain. Specifically, that changing code in the future will involve
> analysis of not only the project code but also the junit test code - an
> overhead we don't have today of course.

Tests are not overhead; they are the safety net that /enables/ you to
make changes confidently. They /save/ you time & effort. Without tests,
how do you know that a change you made didn't break something?

If a simple change to code results in a tedious change to tests, then
you have a design problem that needs to be addressed. It's tough to be
more specific without discussing a specific case. In that case, call in
an expert.

> Has anyone applied junit on a large scale such as this? I'd love to hear
> comments about pros & cons and lessons learned etc.

Bottom line: do you want it to work or not? If you want it to work, you
have to test it. If you can find a better way than JUnit, then do it. :)

Sometimes it just requires a lot of work. Big systems require big work
-- that makes sense to me. The tricky part is distinguishing these two
situations:

1. It takes big work because it's big.
2. It takes big work because the design sucks in a specific way.

How do you learn to distinguish them? With experience.

Start slowly, and when you get into trouble, call in the experts.
Informally you can use the mailing list, and if your company needs a
larger level of support, then let me know and we can explore more
cost-effective means of providing better support.

Good luck!
